Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: I sat in the back seat, my knees bouncing as we drove through the unfamiliar town. My parents had asked me to lead the blessing at our family’s Shabbat dinner tonight—a big deal, since it was the first time all the cousins and grandparents would be together in years. I knew how important it was to them, to keep our traditions alive, to show that I was learning and growing into my role in the family. But my stomach rumbled, and I remembered that we hadn’t eaten since morning. My mom pointed out the small vendor by the roadside, the only kosher-certified place for miles. The line was long, and we were already running late. My dad hesitated, glancing at his watch, then at me. If we stopped, we’d risk being late for the ceremony, and I might not have time to prepare. If we didn’t, I’d be hungry and distracted, maybe even too weak to lead the prayers properly. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing down on me—my family’s hope that I’d honor our traditions, and my own commitment to keeping kosher, even when it wasn’t easy.
